 How Vespas Work -sponsored by-
  People choose to
drive scooters for a number of reasons, not the least of which is the
exceptional gas mileage a scooter can provide. Most scooters can
achieve better miles per gallon ratings than ordinary cars, but the
Vespa gets 60-70 miles per gallon, matching even the most eco-friendly
hybrid cars. Learn how Vespas are made, the history behind them and why they're so popular.
 Also at HowStuffWorks

How OnStar Works - There's no denying its convenience, but some people call the
popular telematics service "Big Brother" and claim that it can lead
to an invasion of privacy. Explore the technology behind -- and controversy
around -- OnStar.

2008 Buick LaCrosse Super Review and Prices - Younger car buyers tend to think of Buicks as old-folks'
cars -- if they think of Buicks at all. The Supers are the latest attempt by
the long-suffering brand to rejuvenate its image. Find out what's new about the
2008 Buick LaCrosse Super.



How Differentials Work - Your car's differential transmits engine power to the wheels
while allowing them to rotate at different speeds, so one wheel doesn't have to
slip when you make a turn. See how differentials work and why cars need
them.



This Week's Video



How the Denso Drowsiness Monitor Works - How do you know when you're too tired to operate a vehicle
safely? A new piece of technology could tell you. Denso is pioneering a drowsiness
monitoring system for automobiles. Find out more in this HowStuffWorks
video.
